sen.j: 正親町 実豊（おおぎまち さねとよ、元和 (日本)5年12月8日 (旧暦)（1620年1月12日） - 元禄16年2月3日 (旧暦)（1703年3月19日））は、江戸時代前期の公家。
sen.e: Sanetoyo OGIMACHI (January 12, 1620-March 19, 1703) was a kuge (court noble) in the early part of the Edo Period.
Sanetoyo OGIMACHI (January 12, 1620-March 19, 1703) was a kuge (court noble) in the early part of the Edo Period.
Sanetoyo OGIMACHI (January 12, 1620-March 19, 1703) was a kuge (court noble) in the early part of the Edo period.

sen.j: おもに後光明天皇（110代）・後西天皇（111代）・霊元天皇（112代）の三代に仕えた。
sen.e: He mainly served the three emperors: the Emperor Gokomyo (110th), the Emperor Gosai (111th) and the Emperor Reigen (112th).
He mainly served the three emperors: the Emperor Gokomyo (110th), the Emperor Gosai (111th) and the Emperor Reigen (112th).
He mainly served the three emperors: the Emperor Gokomyo (110th), the Emperor Gosai (111th) and the Emperor Reigen (112th).

sen.j: 正親町季俊（正四位上参議）の子。
sen.e: He was a son of Suetoshi OGIMACHI (Sangi (councilor) in Shoshiinojo (Senior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade)).
He was a son of Suetoshi OGIMACHI (Sangi (councilor) in Shoshiinojo (Senior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade)).
He was a son of Suetoshi OGIMACHI (Sangi (councilor) in Shoshiinojo (Senior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade)).

sen.j: 母は木村勝盛（従五位下越前守）の娘。
sen.e: His mother was a daughter of Katsumori KIMURA (Echizen no kami (Governor of Echizen Province) in Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
His mother was a daughter of Katsumori KIMURA (Echizen no kami (Governor of Echizen Province) in Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).
His mother was a daughter of Katsumori KIMURA (Governor of Echizen Province in Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)).
sen.cmt: カッコの不足分を追加、Echizen no kami (Governor of Echizen Province)→Governor of Echizen Provinceのみとしました。

sen.j: 元和 (日本)7年（1621年）に叙任し、寛永10年（1633年）に元服のうえ、従五位上侍従に昇進した。
sen.e: He was ordained in 1621 and was promoted to jiju in Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade) after genpuku (celebrate one's coming of age) in 1633.
He was ordained in 1621 and was promoted to jiju in Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade) after genpuku (celebrate one's coming of age) in 1633.
He was ordained in 1621 and was promoted to jiju in Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade) after genpuku (celebrate one's coming of age) in 1633.

sen.j: その後、右近衛少将、右近衛中将、蔵人頭などを歴任し、正保元年（1644年）に参議となり、公卿に列する。
sen.e: After that, he had held positions such as Ukone no shosho (Minor Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards), Ukone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) and Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), and was promoted to Sangi and raised to the peerage as Kugyo (the top court officials) in 1644.

After that, he had held positions such as Ukone no shosho (Minor Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards), Ukone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) and Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), and was promoted to Sangi and raised to the peerage as Kugyo (the top court officials) in 1644.

After that, he had held positions such as Ukone no shosho (Minor Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards), Ukone no chujo (Middle Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) and Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), and was promoted to Sangi and raised to the peerage as Kugyo (the top court officials) in 1644.

sen.j: その後、中納言をへて、明暦2年（1656年）に従二位権大納言となるが、万治元年（1658年）には辞した。
sen.e: And through the position of Chunagon (middle counselor), he was promoted to Gon Dainagon in Junii (Junior Second Rank) in 1656, but resigned in 1658.
And through the position of Chunagon (middle counselor), he was promoted to Gon Dainagon in Junii (Junior Second Rank) in 1656, but resigned in 1658.
And through the position of Chunagon (vice-councilor of state), he was promoted to Gon Dainagon (provisional chief councilor of state) in Junii (Junior Second Rank) in 1656, but resigned in 1658.
sen.cmt: Chunagon→統一表記に修正、Gon Dainagonの補足追加

sen.j: 寛文4年（1664年）から寛文10年（1670年）の間には武家伝奏役をつとめた。
sen.e: He had been in charge of bukedenso-yaku (an officer who communicated with bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)) from 1664 to 1670.
He had been in charge of bukedenso-yaku (an officer who communicated with bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)) from 1664 to 1670.
He had been in charge of bukedenso-yaku (an officer who communicated with bakufu, or Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) from 1664 to 1670.

sen.j: 後水尾法皇崩御後、霊元天皇が親政を開始したが、霊元天皇は大の幕府嫌いであり、武家伝奏役にあったせいか、実豊は親幕派と睨まれ、天和 (日本)3年（1683年）より蟄居を命じられた。
sen.e: When the Emperor Reigen began the direct administration after the death of the Cloistered Emperor Gomizunoo, Sanetoyo fell into disfavor with him as "pro-bakufu clique" partly because the Emperor Reigen hated bakufu and because he was in charge of bukedenso-yaku, and was ordered to be placed in confinement at home since 1683.

When the Emperor Reigen began direct administration after the death of the Cloistered Emperor Gomizunoo, Sanetoyo fell into disfavor with him as "pro-bakufu clique" partly because the Emperor Reigen hated the bakufu and because he was in charge of bukedenso-yaku, and was ordered to be placed in confinement at home since 1683.

When the Emperor Reigen began direct administration after the death of the Cloistered Emperor Gomizunoo, Sanetoyo fell into disfavor with him as "pro-bakufu clique" partly because the Emperor Reigen hated the bakufu and because he was in charge of bukedenso-yaku, and was ordered to be placed in confinement at home since 1683.

sen.j: その後、天皇の譲位とともに赦免された。
sen.e: Later, he was pardoned at the time of the abdication of the throne of the emperor.
Later, he was pardoned at the time of the abdication of the throne of the emperor.
Later, he was pardoned at the time of the abdication of the throne of the emperor.
He died in 1703.
He died in 1703.
He died in 1703.
He was 85 years old.
He was 85 years old.
He was 85 years old.

sen.j: 家督は子の正親町公通が継いだ。
sen.e: The family estate was succeeded by his son Kinmichi OGIMACHI.
The family estate was succeeded by his son Kinmichi OGIMACHI.
The family estate was succeeded by his son Kinmichi OGIMACHI.
